mdRecord.dcterms:description: Sunna is one of the seven Saxon Deities commissioned by Richard Temple, 1st Viscount Cobham (1675–1749) for the gardens at Stowe House in Buckinghamshire. Each god was traditionally associated with a day of the week, with Sunna representing Sunday. Originally placed in an open grove around an altar, by 1744 the statues were repositioned around the Gothic Temple of Liberty, designed by William Kent, and formed an integral part of the underlying political theme of the garden. The Saxon gods are tied in with the political iconography of Stowe, and symbolise Lord Cobham’s allegiance to the ideals of those Whigs who had broken away from Sir Robert Walpole. As such they symbolise an ancient British identity. -- https://collections.vam.ac.uk/item/O66624/sunna-figure-rysbrack-john-michael/ [work]
